Group Description: Writing logs to local file system is not suitable for Container environment
Solution Brief: Redirct logs to STDOUT which will be aggregated by Splunk

Group Description: File based Configuration is not suitable for Container environment
Solution Brief: Externalize Configuration to OpenShift ConfigMap

Group Description: Usage of Local Storage/Files is not recommended in containers because of its ephemeral nature
Solution Brief: Usage of Local Storage/Files is not recommended in containers because of its ephemeral nature.  Different scenarios for usage of local storage of files and their corresponding solution approaches are documented in wiki. Refer wiki
Externalize Registry Usage to ConfigMap

Group Description: Hard coded config data such as IP addresses, uris, conenction strings, credentials creates security vulnerability
Solution Brief: Found hard-coded URIs. Make configurable, put into environment or config map

Group Description: Windows and IIS server dependency. Not supported in .netCore targeting linux
Solution Brief: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/host-and-deploy/iis/modules?view=aspnetcore-7.0

Several technologies available to .NET Framework libraries aren't available for use with .NET 6+, such as app domains, remoting, and code access security (CAS). If your libraries rely on one or more of these technologies, consider the alternative approaches mentioned here 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/porting/net-framework-tech-unavailable

Group Description: Use of encrypted sections and Windows certificate stores is problematic in a cloud environment
Solution Brief: Configurations should be externalized as environment variables and decouple certificates and SSL from your application

Group Description: Cloud native Apps should be executed as a stateless process
Solution Brief: Do not rely on a local filesystem to store information, configuration or logs. Some alternatives could be cloud storage (buckets), storing data in a shared database

Group Description: Relying on the local filesystem to store state is unreliable in a cloud platform. Containers are ephemerals and data could be lost
Solution Brief: Data could be stored in database or the application should leverage File Sharing Systems like NFS Persistent Volume (PV) in Kubernetes environment

Group Description: Launching additional processes and running windows service within a container like environment is not recommended
Solution Brief: Use one service per container and Windows services should be turned into their own deployable console application

Group Description: Logging to the Event Logs and local files is not recommended for cloud native app
Solution Brief: Write to or manage logfiles. Instead, each running process should write its event stream, unbuffered, to stdout

Group Description: Legacy technologies such as appdomain, remoting are not supported in .NET core
Solution Brief:
Several technologies available to .NET Framework libraries aren't available for use with .NET 6+, such as app domains, remoting, and code access security (CAS). If your libraries rely on one or more of these technologies, consider the alternative approaches mentioned here 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/porting/net-framework-tech-unavailable

Group Description: Windows Forms module is not supported in the cloud
Solution Brief: Refactor to a web application

Windows Integrated Authentication will be problematic in the cloud as containers won't be joining Windows Domains. Use another authentication mechanism more cloud friendly like SSO, LDAP Remote Calls, Local...

Group Name: Usage of IHttpContextAccessor to get IP Address

MSMQ is a proprietary Windows server-based messaging solution that is not supported by Linux based containers. Leverage bridging solutions like https://kubemq.io/helping-net-msmq-based-services-to-migrate-to-kubernetes/ on kubernetes

Group Name: Usage of URI Cache IIS Module
Solution Brief: Windows and IIS server dependency. Not supported in .netCore targeting linux. Implements a generic cache for URL-specific server state; such as configuration. With this module; the server only reads configuration for the first request for a particular URL. And reuse it on subsequent requests until it changes.
